channel.title: [pi] 317 Rsps comma support?

item.title: [pi] 317 Rsps comma support?
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

That error is due to the fact that you haven’t imported the DecimalFormat class. Quick thing to know: importing is when you call a class(i.e. “.java”) that isn’t already in your project and access certain methods from within the class. In this case, you must import DecimalFormat in order to use what I showed you.

import java.text.DecimalFormat; Add that code to where your other imports are at the top of the file.

To answer your above question, what I gave you was simply a basic example of how to make use of the DecimalFormat class.

Read full topic

item.title: [pi] 317 Rsps comma support?
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

Using the DecimalFormat class, you can.

[code] String number = “403042534534”;
int amount = Integer.parseInt(number);
DecimalFormat format = new DecimalFormat("#,###");

	System.out.println(format.format(amount));

[/code]

item.title: [pi] 317 Rsps comma support?
item.dc:creator: @framexile framexile
item.description:
@framexile wrote:

Hello the title says it all, is any tut someone can link me to so numbers over 1,000 has comma support instead of 1000? Cause my xp drop rate only shows 1000 total xp not 1,000 and so on. Easy question im sure, not sure what to search for comma support, i tried and nothing showed except 1 tut for money pouch gave me this code for Misc.java didnt work, but please help.

Misc.java

public static String insertCommas(String str) { if (str.length() < 4) { return str; } return insertCommas(str.substring(0, str.length() - 3)) + "," + str.substring(str.length() - 3, str.length()); }

Read full topic
